story.title: A Volcano Erupts
story.author: Scott Robinson
story.text: Look out below! Hot liquid rock is below the ground. Volcanoes are openings in the ground where that liquid can come out. Sometimes, volcanoes erupt. That means they explode. Smoke and hot liquid rock come out of the volcano. The liquid is called lava. Lava can move slowly. It can also move quickly. Lava is dangerous for people, animals, and plants. Some experts study volcanoes. They try to figure out when volcanoes might erupt. Then people can get to a safe place before trouble starts.

questions.text: What are openings in the Earth where hot liquid rock can come out?
What does it mean if a volcano erupts?
What comes out of the volcano when a volcano erupts?
What is another name for the hot liquid rock that comes out of a volcano?

story.title: Hot, Wet, and Muddy
story.text: Chloe and her family were on a trip to a rain forest. "The rain forest is very hot," said Chloe. Chloe was looking for birds. There were so many trees. Chloe could see only little pieces of sky. Plop! A big raindrop fell on Chloe's face. "The rain forest is very wet," said Chloe. Chloe took another step. Uh-oh! Chloe slipped and fell in the mud. "The rain forest is very muddy. But I am the muddiest!" said Chloe.

questions.text: Where were Chloe and her family?
What is the weather like in the rain forest?
What plant blocks out most of the sky in the rain forest?
What did Chloe learn about the rain forest when a raindrop fell on her face?

story.title: The Treasure Map
story.text: Nate's mom drew a map of the park. It was a treasure map. Nate and his mom walked to the park with Nate's friend Kim. Kim would be Captain Blue Shoes. Nate would be Captain Red Beard. The children looked at the map. It said the treasure was near the swings. The captains sneaked behind the slide. They ran by the seesaw. They crawled under the swings. Mom had left two pirate hats there. "We found the treasure!" shouted Captain Blue Shoes.

questions.text: Who is this story about?
What do Kim and Nate use to find the treasure in the park?
Where does the treasure map say the treasure is?
Where did "the captains" go after they sneaked behind the slide?

story.title: Edison Tried and Tried Again
story.text: Thomas Edison was a scientist. He was born in 1847. He invented many things. One was a light bulb that could stay lit for hours. Edison worked very hard. He tried many times to get the light bulb right. Some people say it took 1,000 tries. Edison was asked how he felt about that. He was happy. He said he knew 999 things that do not work. Edison did not give up.

questions.text: Which scientist and inventor is this passage about?
What did Thomas Edison work hard to invent?

story.title: The Flying Machine
story.text: Long ago, a man named Leonardo da Vinci lived. He wanted to build a flying machine. He watched birds fly. He watched bats fly. He watched kites fly. Then he built his flying machine. He could not make it fly. He tried many different ideas. But those ideas did not work. Humans would not fly for 400 more years. Two brothers in the United States made a flying machine. That machine worked. It was an airplane!

questions.text: What did Leonardo da Vinci want to build?
What did Leonardo Da Vinci watch to help him build his flying machine?
Did Leonardo Da Vinci make a flying machine that worked?

story.title: Who Is a Good Citizen at School?
story.author: Woodley Wonderworks
story.text: Good citizens at school help other people. They follow the class rules. Good citizens do their school jobs. They talk nicely to one another. They do their best to answer the teacher's questions. They work together with other students. Good citizens are kind. They do not make fun of others. Are you a good citizen at school?

questions.text: If you want to be a good citizen at school, how should you behave?

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: follow the rules and do your jobs

questions.text: How do good citizens talk to one another?
What kind of student does his or her best to answer the teacher's questions?
How do good citizens treat others?

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: They help others and are kind.

story.title: Ben Franklin's Idea
story.text: Ben Franklin invented things. He liked to read too. He went to the library a lot. Franklin had a problem. Some books were on high shelves. They were hard to reach. Franklin had an idea. He made a tool. He called it the long arm. It was a pole with a claw at one end. The claw was like a hand. Franklin pulled a cord to open and close the claw. Now he could reach the high books!

questions.text: Who is this passage about?
What did Ben Franklin like to do?
What did Ben Franklin have trouble doing when he was at the library?
What did Ben Franklin invent to solve his problem?

story.title: Finding the Office
story.text: Corey's teacher asked him to bring a note to the school's office. Corey walked down the long hall. He saw Ms. Ross, the custodian, cleaning the floor. He saw Mr. Banks, the music teacher, teaching his class a new song. He saw Mr. Ramirez, the assistant principal, talking to a teacher. When Corey got to the office, he saw Mrs. Franks, the secretary. He handed her the note. "Thank you, Corey!" said Mrs. Franks.

questions.text: Where did Corey bring his teacher's note?
Who did Corey see first on his way to the office?
What was Mr. Banks, the music teacher, doing when Corey passed his room?
Who did Corey see talking to a teacher just before he got to the office?

story.title: George Washington's Cherry Tree
story.text: George Washington was America's first president. There is an old story people tell to show that he was honest. In the story, George was six years old. He chopped down his father's cherry tree. His father was angry. His father asked, "Who cut down my favorite tree?" Young George looked at his father. He said, "I cannot tell a lie. I cut down the tree." But his father was not mad. He was happy that his son was honest.

questions.text: Who was George Washington?
In the story about George Washington, what did George do that made his father angry?
What did George Washington say when his father asked him, "Who cut down my favorite tree?"
George told the truth, how did his father feel?

story.title: A Community of People
story.text: What is a community? It is a group of people. They live near one another. They work and play near one another too. The place they live in can be a city or a town. People work in a community. They can help one another. People have different jobs. There are teachers and firefighters. Some people are police officers. Some people are doctors. Some people deliver mail. Some people work in stores. Kids have jobs too. They go to school to learn. What do you like about your community?

questions.text: What do we call a group of people who live, work, and play near one another?
Where can communities be?
What do the grown-ups in a community do to help one another?
What job do the kids in a community have?

story.title: Who Can Pull Harder?
story.text: Tug-of-war is a game. It takes a lot of energy. Two teams play. They face each other. Members of both teams hold on to one rope. Each team pulls the rope. The team that pulls harder moves the rope. Wait! The other team can move the rope too. If the other team pulls just as hard, the rope stops. Then they may pull the rope in the other direction. The teams move the rope back and forth. One big pull can end the game. The stronger team wins.

questions.text: What game is this passage about?
What do the players hold on to in tug-of-war?
What is each team trying to do when they pull on the rope?
If both teams pull just as hard, how will the rope move?

story.title: The Liberty Bell
story.text: Have you seen the Liberty Bell? It is a symbol of America. It is a very big bell. The bell was made in 1753. It was rung to call people together. The bell cracked soon after it was made. People fixed the bell. Then the bell cracked again! It has not been rung since. Now the bell hangs in a museum. It is in Philadelphia. That is a city in Pennsylvania. Many people visit the museum. They want to see the Liberty Bell. They also want to see the crack!

questions.text: The Liberty Bell is a symbol of which country?
Why did people ring the Liberty Bell?
What happened to the Liberty Bell soon after it was made?

story.title: Jon Follows School Rules
story.text: Jon was in kindergarten. He liked it a lot. His teacher talked about school rules. Jon wanted to follow them. Here is what Jon did. He put up his hand to talk. He stood quietly in line. He took turns with others. Jon used his inside voice. At the end of the day, his teacher said, "You did a good job, Jon!"

questions.text: What did Jon want to do in school?
What did Jon do to show that he wants to talk?
What school rule should you follow when working with others?
What happens when Jon follows school rules?

story.title: Spying the Signs
story.text: Laura's family is going to see Aunt Rosa and her new baby. They are on the bus. Laura and her brother Daniel play I Spy. Laura sees a stop sign. "I spy something red. It has eight sides," she tells Daniel. Daniel finds it. "It's a stop sign," says Daniel. Then it is Daniel's turn. "I spy a white H inside a blue square," says Daniel. "That is a hospital sign," says Laura. "We are here!"

questions.text: Who are Laura and her family going to visit?
What do Laura and her brother play on the bus?
What sign does Laura spy?
What does the hospital sign that Daniel spies look like?

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: white H inside a blue square

story.title: Frogs Have Special Skin
story.text: Have you ever seen a frog in a pond? You can often spot one there. Most frogs live near water. They need to keep their skin wet. A frog's skin is special. It makes a slimy coating that helps the frog stay wet. A frog drinks through its skin. It also breathes through its skin. A frog can do that only when its skin is wet. Frogs also breathe using lungs. What else do frogs use lungs for? Frogs make noise. Ribbit!

questions.text: What do most frogs live near?
Frogs like to live near water because they need to stay wet. What part of a frog needs to stay wet?
What can a frog do through its skin (when it is wet)?

story.title: My School
story.text: Hi! My name is Hanna. I live in a small town. My school is on 11 Apple Road. The road has a lot of houses and trees. My school is on a hill. The building is made of red bricks. A park is on the left side of my school. On the right side of my school is a yellow house. The fire station is across the street from my school. Behind the school is a blue house. The blue house is on Valley Street. My house is at the bottom of that street. I am close enough to walk to school!

questions.text: What is the school's address?
What is the school made of?
What color are the two houses that are right by the school?
Hanna lives close to his school. How does Hanna get to school?

story.title: Me and My Shadow
story.text: It was a bright, sunny day. Stella and her mom took a walk. "Look, Mom," said Stella. She pointed to the ground. "I can see my shadow!" "Right," said her mom. "Your body blocks the sun. The place where the light is blocked is your shadow. Watch this," Stella's mom said. She moved her fingers. Their shadow looked like a flying bird. She put out her arm. The shadow looked like a wiggly snake. Stella laughed. "This is fun in the sun!" she said.

questions.text: Who is this story about?
What was the weather like for Stella's walk?
What does Stella see on the ground?
What do we call the place where light is blocked by your body?

story.title: Watch the Tennis Ball
story.text: Tennis is a sport. Players use a racket to hit a small ball. The ball moves through the air. The player swings the racket. When the racket and ball meet, they collide. The ball and racket push on each other. The ball changes direction. It flies through the air. The racket keeps moving. It does not fly through the air. Why? The player is holding it.

questions.text: What sport is this passage about?
What do you need to play Tennis?
When the ball and racket meet and push on each other, what happens to the ball?
Why doesn't the racket fly through the air when it hits the ball?

answerChoices.label: A
answerChoices.text: The player is holding the racket.

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: The racket is on the floor.

story.title: A Sticky Idea
story.text: Have you ever put a sticky bandage on a cut? The best-known sticky bandages are called Band-Aids. They were invented in 1920. A man named Earle Dickson invented Band-Aids. Earle wanted to help his wife. She often cut her fingers when she cooked. At the time, people had to make their own bandages. They cut pieces of gauze and tape. Those bandages were hard to use. Earle's idea was easy to use. Thanks, Earle!

questions.text: What did Earle Dickson invent in 1920?
What often happened to Earl's wife when she cooked?
What did people do when they got a cut in 1920?

story.title: Rain Forest Plants are Helpers
story.text: The rain forest is a warm and wet place. Many kinds of plants grow there. Some of those plants have special parts. Those parts can be used to make medicines. The medicines help sick people. They help some sick people get well. Scientists keep looking in the rain forest. They want to find more plants. More plants can help us find new medicines.

questions.text: What kind of place is a rain forest?
What grows in the rain forest?
What can rain forest plants be used to make?
Who can the medicines from rain forest plants help?

story.title: Kai's Life in Hawaii
story.text: Kai lives in Hawaii. Hawaii is part of the United States. Hawaii is made up of islands. Hawaii is a warm place to live. Here is a day in Kai's life. Kai wakes up early. He eats cereal and papaya. Papaya is a fruit. It is orange and sweet. Then Kai goes to school. He learns math and art today. After school, it starts to rain. It rains for a short time. Then Kai goes to the beach. He surfs with his older brother. They try to ride the waves. Then they go home for dinner. Kai eats and does his homework. Then Kai gets ready for bed.

questions.text: Where does Kai live?
What is the weather like in Hawaii?
What does Kai eat for breakfast?
What does Kai do after he goes home for dinner?

story.title: Paddle a Canoe
story.text: A canoe is a small boat. It holds about two people. How do you make a canoe move in the water? Wear a life jacket, so you are safe. Sit down in the canoe. Pick up a paddle. The paddle has a handle at one end. It has a blade at the other end. The blade goes into the water. Push the blade against the water. Pushing the blade makes the boat move forward. A bigger push makes the boat go faster. It takes energy to paddle the canoe!

questions.text: What is a canoe?
What should you wear while canoeing to keep safe?
What part of the paddle should you put in the water?
What makes the boat move forward?

story.title: Harry Hits a Homer
story.text: Harry was learning to swing a bat so that he could play baseball. Harry swung the bat but did not hit the ball. "Missed," he said. "Watch the ball, Harry," his dad called. Harry tried again. Missed. On game day, it was Harry's turn to bat. Harry missed the ball. Harry missed the ball again. The last time, Harry swung hard. His bat hit the ball. The ball flew through the air. Harry ran all the way around the bases. Everyone cheered, "A homer for Harry!"

questions.text: What is Harry learning at the beginning of the passage?
What is Harry trying to hit with the bat?
When it is Harry's turn to bat on game day, does he hit the ball on the first try?
What happens to the ball when Harry hits it with the bat?

answerChoices.label: A
answerChoices.text: The ball flew through the air.

story.title: Will You Push or Pull?
story.text: Pretend a red wagon is outside your playroom door. You want to move it into the playroom. Stand in front of the wagon. Take hold of its handle. Give it a pull to bring the wagon into the room. You could try this instead: stand behind the wagon. Put both hands on the wagon's back. Give it a push. That will also bring it into the room. Which way would you choose?

questions.text: What should you pretend you want to do with the wagon?
If you stand in front of the wagon and hold the handle, how can you move the wagon?
Where should you stand if you want to push the wagon?
Where should you put your hands if you want to push the wagon?

story.title: Squanto was a Helper
story.text: Squanto was a Native American who lived long ago. He helped the Pilgrims. The Pilgrims had come from England to North America. The land was new to the Pilgrims. They did not know how to find food. Squanto knew the land well. He spoke English too. He showed the Pilgrims where to catch fish. He taught them how to plant corn. He helped them find berries to eat. The Pilgrims thanked Squanto for helping them.

questions.text: Who was Squanto?
Who knew the land in North America well?
What did the Pilgrims not know how to do when they came to North America?
What language did Squanto know that helped him speak to the Pilgrims?

story.title: Getting Water from a Well
story.text: Getting Water from a Well Long ago, people got water from a well. They made a hole in the ground. They would dig until they found water. A place where they found water was called a well. People lined the inside of the well with stones. They tied a long rope to a pail. A pail is a type of bucket. They dropped the pail down into the well. The pail filled with water. People pulled the pail of water up from the well. They carried water into their homes. They used the water for cooking and cleaning.

questions.text: What do people get from a well?
What did people do to make a well?

answerChoices.label: A
answerChoices.text: dig a hole in the ground

questions.text: What did people drop down into a well to get the water out?
What did people use the water for once they got it out of the well?

story.title: A Day in Kindergarten
story.text: In Keesha's kindergarten classroom, the day started with meeting time. The children sang a song each day. They also talked about the weather. Next, they had show-and-tell. Today Tim talked about his toy spaceship. He passed it around for everyone to see. Then it was reading time. The letter of the week was d. Ms. Clarke read a book about dolphins. The children had time to draw pictures. Keesha drew a picture of her favorite animal. It was a dolphin!

questions.text: How did the day start in Keesha's kindergarten classroom?
What do the children do during meeting time?
What comes after meeting time?
When show-and-tell is over, what time is it?

story.title: From Morning to Night
story.text: It is morning. It is time for a new day to begin. The morning sun appears. It slowly brightens the sky. It is noon. It is the middle of the day. The sun is high in the sky. The sunlight is bright. It is evening. The sunlight becomes less bright. The sun is moving lower in the sky. The sky may change to a reddish color. It is night. The sun is gone from the sky. The sky is dark without sunlight. The moon and the stars shine in the night sky. Tomorrow a new day will begin again.

questions.text: What appears in the sky in the morning?
Where is the sun in the middle of the day?
Where is the sun in the evening?
What can you see in the sky at night?

story.title: When Grandma Was a Girl
story.text: Jay and Susie opened the door. It was Grandma! They asked her to tell a story. She told them a story about her life. It took place many years ago. Grandma was a little girl. She lived on a farm. She had three brothers. All of them had chores to do. Grandma fed the chickens and collected their eggs. One day, Grandma found a rock in one chicken's nest. She was confused. How did that get there? Then her brothers told her it was a joke. Grandma laughed. When they heard the story, Jay and Susie laughed too.

questions.text: Where did Grandma live when she was growing up?
What was one of Grandma's chores?
What did Grandma find in a chicken's nest that did not belong?

story.title: Kareem's Playdate
story.text: Kareem had a playdate. He was going to Bill's tomorrow! They were going to play with their toy cars. That night Kareem said, "Dad, where does Bill live? Is it far away?" Dad said, "Look, I'll show you." Dad made a little map. It showed Kareem's street. It showed the street with the bank on it. It showed Bill's street. "See," said Dad, "Bill lives just two blocks away. We will walk there tomorrow."

questions.text: Who is this story mostly about?
Where is Kareem going tomorrow?
Where does Bill live?
How will Kareem get to his friend Bill's house?

story.title: The Four Seasons
story.text: Some places have four seasons every year. Do you know their names? The seasons are winter, spring, summer, and autumn. Winter is the coldest time of the year. Spring comes next. Many animals are born in spring. Many new plants grow then too. Summer is a time of sunshine and hot weather. In autumn, the weather gets cooler. The leaves fall off trees. Some people call autumn by another name. They call it fall!

questions.text: How many seasons do some places have every year?
Which season is the coldest?
When would you see many baby animals and new plants?
What is the weather like in the summer?

story.title: Juan Wants to Build
story.text: Juan wants to build a toy car. His friend Emma wants to help. Juan tells Emma his idea. Emma is not sure how she can help. Juan gets an idea. He takes out paper and crayons. He draws a picture of a toy car. He draws more pictures showing how he wants to build it. Then Juan tells Emma about the toy car again. He talks while pointing to each picture. Now Emma knows how she can help.

questions.text: Who has an idea for how to build a toy car?
Who wants to help build a toy car but doesn't know how?
What does Juan draw a picture of?

story.title: Save Your Paper
story.text: Help Earth Do you throw away pieces of paper after you use them? You can do something better: Recycle! When you throw things away, they become trash. Too much trash hurts our planet. Also, we would have to cut down more trees to make new paper. That would hurt Earth too. Today many people recycle paper. When used paper is recycled, it is turned into new paper. Less paper is put in the trash. Fewer trees are cut down. Recycling is helpful to Earth!

questions.text: What do your things become when you throw them away?
Why is trash a problem?
What do we need to cut down to make new paper?
What can we make out of recycled paper?

story.title: Luisa builds a Model
story.text: Luisa really likes the neighborhood where she lives. Luisa wants to build a model of it. She finds some cardboard. Her dad cuts it into squares. Luisa colors the squares. She tapes the squares so they could stand up. The model is done. Luisa shows it to her dad. Luisa points to the fire station. Luisa shows her dad the market. He points to a red house. Then he smiles. "Isn't that our house?" he says. "Yes!" says Luisa.

questions.text: What does Luisa want to build a model of?
What does she use to make her model?
How does Luisa make the cardboard look like the buildings in her neighborhood?
What buildings does Luisa build from her neighborhood?

story.title: The New House
story.text: Jana's parents bought a new house. The house was still being built. The builder showed the family a model of the house. The builder also showed them a photograph of the house. Jana looked at the picture. It showed that the house had two floors. Next, Jana looked at the model. She opened the tiny front door and peeked inside. She saw a kitchen and a living room. Then Jana looked at the top floor. She saw two bedrooms and a bathroom. Jana was happy to see the model and the picture. Now she was excited to move.

questions.text: What did Jana's parents buy?
What did the builder show Jana's family of the house?
First Jana looked at the picture of the house. What did the picture of her house show?

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: The house had a living room.

questions.text: Next Jana looked at the model. What did Jana see in the top floor of the house?

story.title: Parts of a Tree
story.text: Trees are a kind of plant. They grow like some other plants do. What are the parts of a tree? A tree has leaves. The leaves help make food for the tree. A tree has branches. Branches give trees their shape. A tree has bark. Bark is hard skin on the outside of the tree. A tree has roots. Roots take in water for the tree. How are trees like other plants?

questions.text: What plant is this passage about?
What part of the tree helps make food for the tree?
What gives the tree its shape?
What do we call the hard skin on the outside of the tree?

story.title: City Life and Country Life
story.text: Do you live in a city? A city has many buildings. It also has many roads. It has many cars and lots of noise. Cities are full of people. City life can be full of fun. City life is noisy. Do you live in the country? The country has lots of grass, trees, and animals. It also has farms. People grow food in the country. Fewer people live in the country than in the city. Country life can be full of fun. Country life is quieter.

questions.text: What does a city have a lot of?
Where do people grow food?
Where should you live if you like it to be quiet?
What is the same about the country and the city?

answerChoices.label: A
answerChoices.text: Life can be full of fun.

story.title: Jack's Lost Kite
story.text: Jack could not find his kite. It was not in his bedroom. It was not in the kitchen. "Mom," asked Jack, "have you seen my kite?" "No, Jack," said his mom. "Did you look outside?" Jack looked under the porch. No kite. He looked next to the swings. No kite. He looked behind the house. No kite. "Where could it be?" he thought. Jack looked up. There it was! His kite was stuck in the tree.

questions.text: Who is this story about?
What was Jack looking for?
Where else does Jack look for his kite?

story.title: Traffic Lights
story.text: A traffic light helps people cross the street safely. Here are rules to follow when crossing a street. Always cross with a grown-up. Wait for the light to turn green. Green means go. Look both ways to make sure cars stop. Walk across the street. Remember this poem: Watch a traffic light to know. Red means stop, and green means go. When cars stop, the street is clear. You can cross, and have no fear.

questions.text: What do traffic lights help people do?
Who should you always cross the street with?
What color on the traffic light means go?
How can you make sure that all cars stop?

story.title: Page not Found
story.text: The Longest and Shortest Days When is the longest day of the year in the United States? It is around June 21. That is the first day of summer. It is called the summer solstice. Summer days are long. We have many hours of sunlight. Why? Earth tilts as it travels around the sun. In the summer, the north half of Earth tilts toward the sun. The United States is in Earth's north half. What is the shortest day of the year? It is around December 21. That is the winter solstice. It is the first day of winter. In the winter, Earth's north half tilts away from the sun.

questions.text: What do we call the first day of summer?
During which season are the days long?
What do we call the first day of winter?
Are winter days long or short?

story.title: How Plants Work
story.text: Every part of a plant has a job to do. The leaves make food for the plant. Leaves use sunlight to make food. The stem holds the plant up. Without a strong stem, the plant would fall down. The roots grow underground. Roots take in water for the plant. Flowers look pretty, but they have a job too! They make sure new plants will grow. Seeds grow inside flowers. The seeds will fall to the ground. Many of the seeds will grow into new plants.

questions.text: What do leaves use to make food for plants?
What part of a plant holds the plant up so the plant does not fall down?
What part of the plant takes in water?
Where do plant seeds fall to grow into new plants?

story.title: How Trees Help
story.text: Did you know that trees are helpers? Trees are plants that clean our air. There is a gas in the air that can be dangerous to people. Tree leaves take in that gas. The leaves use that gas to make food for the tree. Then the leaves give off a clean gas. The clean gas goes into the air for us to breathe. Trees also give us shade on hot days. Trees give us food to eat. Trees give some animals homes. Thank you, trees!

questions.text: What plant does this passage say is a helper?
How can trees help us on hot days?
What do some trees give us to eat?
What part of the tree takes in gas from the air?

story.title: Cloudy and Sunny
story.text: This morning it was cloudy. Maria and her friends went outside. They played tag. Then the sun came out. The sun felt warm. The air got warmer and warmer. Maria felt very warm. She needed to take a break. She sat down under a tree. It was cooler in the shade. Maria smiled. She waved to her friends. "Cool off with me in the shade!" said Maria.

questions.text: Who is this story about?
Where are Maria and her friends playing?
What is the weather like at the end of the story?
Why did Maria take a break?

story.title: Take Care of Your Teeth!
story.text: You need healthy teeth. Do you know why? Your teeth help you eat. They help you talk. Here are some ways to care for your teeth: ? Brush your teeth after you eat. ? Eat healthful foods. ? Have a grown-up help you floss your teeth. ? Visit the dentist two times each year. And don't forget to smile!

questions.text: What do you need to help you eat and talk?
What should you do after you eat to care for your teeth?
What kind of food should you eat?
Who can help you floss your teeth?

story.title: How Plants Get Water and Food
story.text: Most plants have roots. Those roots grow down into the dirt. The roots take in water from the dirt. The roots also take in minerals and other things from the dirt. A plant uses those things to help it make food. The water and food then move up the plant's stem. They move to other parts of the plant. This helps the plant grow well.

questions.text: Where do roots grow?
What do roots take in from the dirt for the plant?
What does water and food move up through to other parts of the plant?
What happens to plants that get plenty of food and water?

story.title: Jos and the Blue Crayons
story.text: Jos, Ella, and Alex sat at the same table. They listened to their teacher, Ms. Garcia. Ms. Garcia talked about sharing and taking turns. Then she said the class could draw pictures. Ms. Garcia put a big box of crayons on each table. Jos took all three blue crayons. He drew water and the sky and a sailboat. Ella looked sad. "I need a blue crayon," she told Jos. Jos gave Ella one of the blue crayons. "I like to share!" he said.

questions.text: Where do Jos, Ella, and Alex sit in school?
What do the students at each table need to share to color their pictures?
What does Jos take from the box of crayons at his table?
is Ella sad?

story.title: Racing Cars Can Go!
story.text: Mario wants to try his new set of racing cars. He leans a board against his bed to make a ramp. He gently pushes each car down the ramp. The cars move smoothly down. Mario wants to see if they will go faster. He gives each car a bigger push. Now cars move down the ramp faster. Vroom! They make a racing sound. The cars go in different directions. "These cars are neat!" Mario says.

questions.text: What new toy is Mario playing with?
What does Mario make for his racing cars by leaning a board against his bed?
Mario wants to see if his racing cars will go faster. What does he do to the racing cars to see if they will go faster?

answerChoices.label: A
answerChoices.text: He gives each car a bigger push.

questions.text: Mario gives his racecars a bigger push, what direction do they go?

story.title: The Winning Shot
story.text: The soccer game was nearly over. Time had almost run out. The two teams were tied, one to one. Amber kicked the ball. Oh no! She kicked it the wrong way. She kicked it toward the school building. "What a bad kick," Amber thought. But wait! One of her teammates, John, jumped to stop the ball. The ball went off John and into the goal! Amber's team won the game. Hooray! It was not a bad kick, after all.

questions.text: What game is Amber playing?
Amber thinks she kicked the ball the wrong way. Which building did she kick it towards?
Who jumped to stop the ball?
Where does the ball go after it bounces off John?

story.title: Finding Food
story.text: Long ago, getting food was a lot of work. There were no stores to buy food. People had four ways to get food. They farmed crops such as corn and beans. They hunted for deer, rabbits, and other animals. They went fishing for food such as trout and eels. They searched in the forest for food that grew wild, such as nuts and berries. Getting food then was not easy. Today most people can get the food they need at a store. Now getting food is easier and faster.

questions.text: Is it easier and faster to get food today or was it easier long ago?
How did people get corn and beans in the past?
What could people hunt for?

story.title: Fun on the Playground
story.text: "It's time for recess," Ms. Roberto said. It was bright and sunny outside. The children went out to the playground. Ava and Glenda went on the swings. Next, they climbed up to the tower. They sat at the top and then went down a curvy slide. Ms. Roberto was smiling and watching them. "Recess is over," she said. "Can we play again tomorrow?" Ava asked. "Yes, if it is sunny like today," Ms. Roberto said.

questions.text: What is it time for at the beginning of the story?
Where are the children having recess?
Where did Ava and Glenda play during recess?
what did Mrs. Roberto do during recess?

story.title: The Bicycle Problem
story.text: Jimmy had a problem with his bicycle. He had a flat tire. Maybe he could ride on one good tire? That didn't work. The bike went bump bump bump. Well, he could buy a new tire. But how could he get to the store? His bike didn't work! Then Lashona came along with an idea. She showed Jimmy how to take off the flat tire. She had a patch to fix a hole in the tire. Jimmy put the tire back on the bike. Then he used Lashona's pump to fill the tire with air again. Now his bike was ready to go!

questions.text: What problem does Jimmy have with his bicycle?
Why can't Jimmy buy a new tire?

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: He can't get to the store.

questions.text: How does Lashona want to solve Jimmy's problem?

story.title: Ant and Grasshopper
story.text: One day a grasshopper hopped along a road and saw an ant. The ant was carrying a big ear of corn. "Hey, stop and talk to me," Grasshopper said. "I am getting food for the winter," Ant said. "You should too." "It is summer. I have food," said Grasshopper. Soon winter came. Grasshopper had no food. Ant and his friends had corn to eat. Grasshopper learned a lesson: it is wise to get ready for the future.

questions.text: Who is this story about?
What was ant doing at the beginning of the story?
what is the lesson of this story?

story.title: Lily Makes Lemonade
story.text: Lily's friends are visiting her today. Olivia bakes oatmeal cookies. Sharon brings chips and dip. Lily makes lemonade. She squeezes four lemons into a pitcher. Next she adds four cups of water. Finally she mixes one teaspoon of sugar into the pitcher. Lily tastes it. "This lemonade is too sour," she says. She adds more sugar. She tastes it again. Now it is much better!

questions.text: Who is visiting Lily's today?
What is Lily making?
What does Lily use to make lemonade?
what does Lily do to make her lemonade taste better?

story.title: Walt's Class Watches the Weather
story.text: Walt's class was learning about weather. Mrs. Lin, their teacher, made a weather chart. She made five boxes. In each box, she wrote down one day of the week: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Each day, Mrs. Lin asked what the weather was like. On Monday, Susie said it was rainy. Susie drew a picture of a rainy day in the box that said "Monday." On Tuesday, Walt said it was sunny. Mrs. Lin asked Walt to draw the picture. In the box marked "Tuesday," Walt drew a big yellow sun.

questions.text: What is Walt's class learning about?
What does Walt's class use to record the weather?
What does Mrs. Lin write in each box on the class's weather chart?
when did Susie say that the weather was rainy?

story.title: The United States of America
story.text: Americans live in the United States of America. Millions of people live in America. People come here from all over the world. Why? Many come here because they want a better life. People in America may not look the same. They may not eat the same foods. They may not have the same beliefs. They may speak different languages. What do they have in common? They live in the United States. Many of them love their country.

questions.text: Why do many people come from all over the world to live in America?

answerChoices.label: B
answerChoices.text: They want to be near the ocean.

questions.text: People in America are not all the same. What may be different about them?
What do people in America have in common?

answerChoices.label: A
answerChoices.text: They live in the United States.

story.title: Wow, Water!
story.text: Our Earth has a lot of water. People need water. Do you know why? We need water to drink. Water keeps our bodies working well. We need water to cook some food. We need water to wash our bodies. How do you use water?

questions.text: What does the Earth have a lot of?
What do we need water for?
what do you need to wash your body?

story.title: Getting Around Alaska
story.text: Alaska is very cold during winter. Snow and ice cover the ground. Not all roads get plowed. How do people get around? They can use skis. Skis help people glide over snow. They can use snowshoes. Snowshoes help people walk on top of snow. They can use dogsleds. A team of strong dogs pulls the sled. One of the fastest ways to travel is by snowmobile. A snowmobile has a motor. A snowmobile has skis on the front. It helps people in snowy places get around quickly. There are many ways to get around, even in deep snow!

questions.text: What covers the ground in Alaska during the winter?
What can people use to glide over snow?
What do snowshoes help you do?
what animal can be used to pull a sled?

story.title: How to Ride a Skateboard
story.text: Would you like to learn how to ride a skateboard? Here is a quick lesson. First put on your safety helmet. Then place one foot on the skateboard. Keep the other foot on the ground. Use the foot on the ground to push. Quick! Put both feet up on the board. Now you are skateboarding! Use a small push to move slowly. Use a bigger push to move faster. Put one foot on the ground to stop. Happy skateboarding!

questions.text: What can you learn to ride from this passage?
What should you always put on first?
How many feet should you have on the skateboard when you want to start skateboarding?
How many feet should you have on the skateboard while skateboarding?

story.title: Caden's Day
story.text: Mom helped Caden get ready for school. Then she walked him to the bus. She gave him a hug. "See you tomorrow!" said Mom. Mom works in the evening. She has an important job. She is a nurse at the hospital. She helps people who are sick or hurt. After school, Dad picked Caden up. He has an important job. He is a teacher. He teaches science. At home, Dad helps Caden do his homework. Later that night, Dad helps Caden get ready for bed. Caden misses his mom. But he knows he will see her again in the morning.

questions.text: Who helps Caden get ready for school?
Where is Caden's mom when he gets home from school?
Where does Caden's mom work?
What job does Caden's Dad have?

story.title: Be Careful With Medicines
story.author: By Susan LaBella
story.text: Sometimes people who do not feel well must take medicine. Doctors give people medicine to help them get better. Anyone who takes medicine must follow safety rules. Take medicine only from a doctor or a grown-up you know and trust. Give any medicine or pills that you find to a grown-up. Make sure medicines are put away safer after they are used. Following these rules will help you stay healthy and safe.

questions.text: What should you do with medicine that you find?
